limited to a circle defined with radius of 363 feet (0.07 miles).  There would be no off site consequence because the closest off site receptor is 1850 feet (0.35 miles).

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

 *  Process safety information
 *  Process hazard analysis
 *  Operating procedures
 *  Training
 *  Mechanical integrity
 *  Management of change
 *  Pre-startup review
 *  Compliance audits
 *  Incident investigation
 *  Employee participation
 *  Hot work permit
 *  Contractors

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

4/9/99      Contaminated sodium chlorate resulted in a decomposition in the generator and an estimated 0.1 pound of chlorine dioxide being released.

3/23/99    The pipe suppling scrubbing medium to the bleach plant scrubber plugged.  The residual chlorine dioxide from the bleaching process was not being scrubbed out.  This resulted in a release of an estimated 8.9 pounds.

9/7/98      The packing in a manual valve in the No. 2 Bleach plant failed allowing a ver

y small amount of liquid to escape.  This resulted in the release of an estimated 0.000028 pounds of chlorine dioxide.

9/7/98       A flange gasket on the chlorine dioxide supply line failed in the No.2 Bleach plant.  This resulted in the release of an estimated 0.00006 pounds of chlorine dioxide.

8/11/98    A temporary process control malfunction allowed the concentration in the solution in the process water treatment system to get excessively high and gas off (come out of solution).  An estimated 0.000052 pounds of chlorine dioxide solution was released.

7/22/98     The vent from the No.2 bleach tower to the bleach plant scrubber became plugged and resulted in an overpressurization of the bleach tower. An estimated 0.0014 pounds of chlorine dioxide was released.

7/17/98     An estimated 0.06 pounds of chlorine dioxide was released when the flow of the scrubbing medium to the bleach plant scrubber was lost.  The loss of flow was traced to an equipment malfunction.

7/10/98     A process control unit malfunctioned resulting in excess supply to the process.  The unused chemical came out of solution (gassed off) in the process sewers.  An estimated 0.000003 pounds of chlorine dioxide solution was released.

4/22/98    A temporary loss of water flow to the generator absorption tower resulted in the release of an estimated 0.46 pounds of chlorine dioxide.

4/13/98    During the startup of the generator, residual chlorine dioxide solution trapped in pipes (undrained from previous startup attempts) allowed the gas to come out of solution.  This resulted in a release of an estimated 0.098 pounds of chlorine dioxide.

10/29/97  The release of an estimated 0.003 pounds of chlorine dioxide occurred when the gasket on the relief hatch of the No.2 Bleach plant tower failed.

9/27/98     The solution storage tank level controler malfunctioned allowing a small amount of solution to overflow from the tank.  An estimated 1.77 pounds of chlorine dioxide was released from the liq

uid spill.

2/3/97       During the routine restart of the generator, the absorption tower water flow was temporarily lost.  This released an estimated 4.5 pounds of chlorine dioxide.

6/14/96    Emissions from the vent of the No.2 Bleach plant tower resulted in the release of an estimated 4.5 pounds of chlorine dioxide.

Summary of Accidental Chemical Releases

1999      two (2) accidental chemical releases todate.
1998      eight (8) accidental chemical releases.
1997      three (3) accidental chemical releases.  
1996      one (1) accidental chemical release. 
1995      no accidental chemical releases.
1994       no accidental chemical releases.

Please note, years 1996, 1997 and 1998 involved major construction activities in the bleach areas.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of improvements that we are planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

The installation of area chlorine dioxide monitors in the bleach plant areas  to alert any operating personnel of the release of chlorine dioxide.  Additionally, Willamette periodically conducts audits of the RMP covered processes and uses the recommendations from those audits to prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Willamette Industries, Kentucky Mills, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

 *  A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
 *  A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
 *  An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
 *  A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
 *  An overview of our emergency response program

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Our facility produces bleached pulp, fine papers and unbleached corrugating medium using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  The bleached pulp uses a kraft pulping process and supplies fiber to the fine paper manufacturing facility.  The corrugating medium uses a combination of semichemical and recycled pulp.  In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

A 1% solution of chlorine dioxide is stored in 140,000 gallon tanks and is used to bleach hardwood kraft pulp.

Flammables

Propane is stored in 1000 gallon tanks and is used to fuel the material handling equipment on site.

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by

our use of these chemicals.

KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:

Worst-case Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

This scenario assumes the rupture of a full, 140,000 gallon tank containing a 1% chlorine dioxide solution and the vaporization of the released solution.  The tank has dikes present to mitigate the extent of the release.  The model suggests the off site consequences would be in the area defined by a circle with the radius of 4.78 miles form the source (mill).  

Alternative Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemicals

This scenario assumes a 1% chlorine dioxide solution process pipe leak.  This leak results in the release of the contents of an eight (8) inch pipe, 250 feet in length. This scenario assumes no mitigation, and a release of 55 pounds of chlorine dioxide that is vapoized from the liquid release.  This model suggests the area impacted by the off site consequences would be defined by a circle with the diameter of 1.3 miles from the release site (mill).

Worst-case Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This scenario assumes that a 1000 gallon propane storage tank has a leak that results in a vapor cloud explosion. It also assumes no mitigation is present.  The model suggests there would be no off site consequences since the model endpoint would be 663 feet (0.12 miles) from the source and the nearest off site receptor in 1850 feet away (0.35 miles)
